a b s t r a c t
Developing simple, rapid, and environmentally friendly synthetic methodologies for the preparation of functional nanomaterials is of great importance for broadening and improving their potential applications. In comparison with other methods, the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method possesses and combines the merits of microwave and hydrothermal methods, which can achieve the high temperature and high pressure for a short time from several minutes to several hours in a closed reaction system. In this review, the synthesis of various types of functional nanomaterials such as metals oxides, metal composite oxides, inorganic biomaterials (hydroxyapatite and calcium carbonate), and metal sulfides via the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method is summarized. The special properties and applications of functional nanomaterials by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method are compared with others methods. The future developments of this promising method are put forward.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrothermal method is to simulate the growth of crystals during the mineralization process in nature, in which the reaction could be completed using water as solvent in a closed system at a certain temperature and pressure. Under hydrothermal conditions, the properties of water such as vapor pressure, density, surface tension, viscosity, and ionic product will be greatly changed. As early as 1882, the hydrothermal method was used to synthesize crystals. It can evidently decrease the reaction temperature of systems, prepare highly crystalline products with narrow size distribution, high purity, and low aggregation. Due to the reaction in the closed system, it is difficulty to observe the growth process of materials. Moreover, the hydrothermal method has a series of shortcomings including high requirements of equipment, long reaction time, and high energy consumption, etc. In the literature, there are many reports on the synthesis of functional

nanomaterials using the hydrothermal method [1]. Various novel and unique shapes could be obtained using this method such as quantum dots, nanowires, nanotubes, nanorods, nanosheets, and so on. In 2007, Yao and Yu published a review article entitled “Recent advances in hydrothermal syntheses of low dimensional nanoarchitectures” [2]. This review gave an overview of advances in hydrothermal syntheses of low dimensional nanoarchitectures before 2007. They discussed the applications of a traditional hydrothermal synthesis method for the rational synthesis of a variety of low dimensional nanostructured materials such as nanorods, nanowires, nanosheets, nanotubes, and their assemblies with controllable size, shape, phase, length scale, and structural complexity.
Microwave is the electromagnetic wave between the infrared radiation and radiowaveswith the frequency at 300MHze300 GHz and the wavelength in the range of 1 me1 mm. During the process of microwave heating, the reaction depended on the interaction between microwave and materials. Under the electromagnetic field, the particles of materials can produce polarization such as electron polarization, atom polarization, orientation polarization, and space charge polarization. In comparison with traditional external heating methods, microwave heating is rapid volumetric heating without the heat conduction process, which can achieve
uniform heating in a short period of time. Zhu and Chen published a review on the microwave-assisted preparation of inorganic nanostructures in liquid phase [3]. They discussed the microwaveassisted preparation of inorganic nanostructures in aqueous solution, polyols, ionic liquids, mixed solvents, etc. They also compared the difference between the microwave-assisted heating and conventional heating. It is well known that the microwave-assisted method is a rapid, energy-saving and promising route for the synthesis of functional nanomaterials. However, the reaction temperature cannot exceed the boiling point of the solvents in the open reaction system. Although the conventional hydrothermal/solvothermal method can obtain the high temperature and high pressure in a closed reaction system, it takes a long time (serveral hours to several days) to complete the reaction temperature. The microwave-assisted hydrothermal/solvothermal method combines the advantages of these two methods, which can rapidly achieve the high temperature and high pressure, and significantly shorten the preparation time (serveral minutes to several hours) in a closed reaction system. Table 1 provided the comparison of the characteristic among the hydrothermal, microwave, and microwaveassisted hydrothermal methods.
In the early 2002, Newalkar and Komarneni accomplished the simplified synthesis of micropore-free hydrothermally stable mesoporous silica SBA-15 using a silica precursor (sodium silicate/ tetraethylorthosilicate) with pluronic 123 copolymer in the presence of co-solvent (hydrochloric acid and ethanol) using a minimum salt (sodium chloride) content, under microwavehydrothermal conditions at 373 K for 120 min [4]. Then, they indicated that the microwave-hydrothermal or microwavesolvothermal method is truly advantageous method for the preparation of nanophase materials with different sizes and shapes due to its advantages of energy saving and environmental friendliness [5]. Xu et al. synthesized a high quality pure hydroxy-sodalite zeolite membrane on the support of a-Al2O3 by microwaveassisted hydrothermal method [6]. It was reported that the synthesis of hydroxy-sodalite zeolite membrane only took 45 min and the microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis was more than 8 times faster than that by the conventional hydrothermal method. Moreover, the pure hydroxy-sodalite zeolite membrane could be easily synthesized by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. However, the conventional hydrothermal method usually resulted in a zeolite membrane consisted of the mixtures of NaX zeolite, NaA zeolite, and hydroxysodalite zeolite. Bondioli et al. also rapidly prepared nanocrystalline Pr-doped ceria powders with uniform sizes of 25e30 nm within 1 h by microwave-assisted hydrothermal route [7]. They evaluated the effect of the microwave treatment compared with the conventional hydrothermal technique. Undoubtedly, the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method has been received more and more attentions and accepted as a promising green synthetic methodology for the preparation of functional nanomaterials.
This review gives an overview on the potential of the microwave-assisted hydrothermal/solvothermal method for the rapid synthesis of functional nanomaterials and their applications. We focus on the differences of the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method compared with conventional methods. Typical examples are introduced to strive to prove that the microwave-
assisted hydrothermal method is not just a combination of microwave treatment and hydrothermal process.

sections.heading: 2. Microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of functional nanomaterials and their applications
2.1. Metal oxides and hydroxides
sections.text: There are many reports on the microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of functional metal oxides and hydroxides nanomaterials with various applications in gas sensor, catalytic applications, electrochemical applications, solar cells applications, optical applications, etc. Table 2 provided the representative summary of the metal oxides and hydroxides via microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Gas sensor applications
sections.text:
Hematite (a-Fe2O3) is known as a promising photo-electrode material due to its significant light absorption, chemical stability, and ferromagnetic resonance. As early as 2007, Hu et al. applied a rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal process to synthesize single-crystalline a-Fe2O3 nanorings in solution [8]. Single a-Fe2O3 nanoring with a circular shape and an average outer diameter of about 100 nm and inner diameters ranging from 20 to 60 nmwere obtained at 220 C for 25 min (Fig. 1B). The fringes separated by ~3.7 Å agrees well with the {012} lattice spacing of the rhombohedral hematite (Fig. 1D). The local elemental composition of the formed nanorings confirms the presence of Fe and O (Fig. 1E). The sensors constructed by the a-Fe2O3 nanorings exhibited high sensitivity not only for bio-sensing of hydrogen peroxide in a physiological solution but also for gas-sensing of alcohol vapor at room temperature. They also reported the microwaveehydrothermal method to synthesize monodisperse a-Fe2O3 nanocrystals with continuous aspect-ratio tuning and fine shape control [9]. The initial molar ratio of Fe3þ to PO43 was found to play a crucial role in the final morphology of the a-Fe2O3 products. A variety of morphologies including ellipsoids/spindles with aspect ratios ranging from 1.1 to 6.3, all nanosheets, nanorings, and spheres were obtained with pH of 1.8e2.3 at 220 C for 10e25 min. The as-formed a-Fe2O3 nanocrystals were reported to exhibit sizeand shape-dependent infrared optical properties. With the increase aspect ratio of the as-formed a-Fe2O3 crystals increases, the absorption of the infrared active modes polarized parallel to the c-axis becomes resolved from the infrared active modes polarized perpendicular to the c-axis at 575 cm 1 for the pseudocubes and shifts to lower wavenumbers, whereas the absorption of the infrared activemodes polarized perpendicular to the c-axis shifts to higher wavenumbers (from 575 to 580 cm 1). The FT-IR spectra of the as-formed a-Fe2O3 nanocrystals with different sizes and shapes suggested that the size and shape affect the peak frequencies and widths. The results suggested that the a-Fe2O3 nanocrystals are also the ideal candidates for studying their nanoarchitecture-dependent performance in optical, catalytic, and magnetic applications.

They suggested that the enhanced gas sensing performance of the sensor to ethanol might be attributed to the small size of the CuO nanorods. Then, they also used this facile method to prepare single-phase monoclinic CuO nanostructures with varying shape (tadpole-shaped, spindly, leaf/ sphere-like and fusiform) at 120 C for 10 min [11]. It was observed that the tadpole-shaped CuO nanostructures displayed the best response of 5 toward 1000 ppm methanol, 7 toward 1000 ppm ethanol, and 8 toward 800 ppm acetone, respectively. Lu et al. prepared ZrO2 nanorods with different dispersibility as a humidity sensor via a facile microwave-hydrothermal approach in the absence of any organic modifiers at 180 C for 2.5 h [12]. The concentration of zirconium precursor was found to significantly affect the dispersion of ZrO2 nanorods, and the lower concentration of zirconium precursor favored the formation of ZrO2 nanorods with higher dispersibility under microwave irradiation. It was reported that the sample with a higher concentration of surface oxygen vacancies exhibited a higher humidity sensor response due to more active sites for water adsorption.
A microwave-assisted hydrothermal technique was reported for the synthesis of mesoporous tetragonal spherical-like SnO2 nanoparticles as a gas sensor with the primary crystallite sizes of 6e8 nm and average pore sizes of about 15 nm at 150 C for 30 min [13]. It was found that the as-synthesized SnO2 nanoparticles showed high thermal stability up to 800 C, which could be used for detection of ethanol because of its nanoscale size and high stability at high temperature. The as-prepared SnO2 nanoparticles exhibited the highest ethanol-sensing at 250 C and good photocatalytic
activity for the oxidation of ethanol. The potential application of the material was proposed for indoor air purification in pharmaceutical and fermentation monitoring and vehicular control through breath analyzer.
Monodisperse WO3 hierarchical spheres were synthesized via the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method and a subsequent annealing process using peroxopolytungstic acid as a precursor in the presence of sodium sulfate at 180 C for 60 min [14]. It is found that the reaction time influenced the morphology in terms of particle size and dispersity. The results revealed that the sensor based on the as-prepared WO3 hierarchical spheres showed relatively good selectivity and repeatability to acetone vapor. When the acetone concentration was in the range of 100e1000 ppm, the relationship between the response and the acetone concentration exhibited a good linearity.
A simple microwave-assisted hydrothermal precipitation technique was reported for the synthesis of Ag@SnO2 coreeshell nanocomposites for the detection of propane at 100e180 C for 15 min [15], in which Ag crystals were synthesized via chemical reduction of metal salt followed by microwave-assisted hydrothermal deposition of tin dioxide shell for the fabrication of monodispersed coreeshell nanocomposites. The as-prepared Ag@SnO2 coreeshell nanocomposites exhibited distinct surface plasmon spectrum in the range of 407e440 nm and the highest propane sensing activity at 250 C. They proposed a soft-sensor model to understand the multi gas sensing ability and selectivity of propane sensing property of the Ag@SnO2 coreeshell nanocomposites based devices.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Catalytic applications
sections.text:
The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was applied for the synthesis of uniform hexagonal WO3 nanowires with a diameters of 5e10 nm and lengths of up to several micrometers at 150 C for 3 h in a solution containing (NH4)2SO4 as a capping reagent and Na2WO4 as a starting material [16]. The aspect ratio and
specific surface area of hexagonal WO3 nanowires were 625 and 139 m2 g 1, respectively. Hexagonal WO3 nanowires displayed high electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction investigated by cyclic voltammetry and linear sweep voltammetry. The results demonstrated that hexagonal WO3 nanowires are a promising electrocatalyst for the hydrogen evolution reaction from water.
Qiu et al. applied a microwave-assisted hydrothermal reaction between Fe(NO3)3 and urea to synthesize uniform a-Fe2O3 nanoparticles with a diameter of about 5.0 nm and a specific surface area of around 173.0m2 g 1 at 120 C for 30min [17]. The as-prepared aFe2O3 nanoparticles displayed excellent catalytic and adsorption performances. For the oxidation of CO and 2-propanol to CO2, CO was oxidized to CO2 over 120 C and completely transformed to CO2 at 170 C, and 2-propanol was fully oxidized to CO2 at 350 C using 0.1 g a-Fe2O3 as a catalyst. In addition, the adsorption capacity for As(III) reached 51.8 mg g 1 in water treatment at room temperature.
Cao et al. synthesized ceria hollow nanospheres composed of CeO2 nanocrystals via a template-free microwave-assisted hydrothermal method at 170 C for 30 min [18]. An Ostwald ripening mechanism coupled with a self-templated and self-assembly process, in which amorphous solid spheres were converted to
crystalline nanocrystals and the latter self-assembled to form hollow structures, was proposed for the formation of the hollow structures. These ceria hollow nanospheres showed a high adsorption capacity for heavy metal ions, for example, 22.4 mg g 1 for As (V) and 15.4 mg g 1 for Cr (VI). These ceria hollow nanospheres were also excellent supports for gold nanoparticles, forming an Au/CeO2 composite catalyst. In the CO oxidation, a 100% CO conversion was achieved at room temperature.
Araujo et al. synthesized CeO2 nanoparticles by the microwaveassisted hydrothermal method at different synthesis temperatures for 16 min [19]. Experimental results showed that the samples synthesized at 80 C consisted of spherical particles of about 5 nm, while those synthesized at 120 C presented a mixture of spherical and rod-like nanoparticles and the sample synthesized at 160 C consisted of nanorods with a 10 nm average diameter and 70 nm length. The anisotropic nanostructures were composed of oriented primary spherical nanoparticles (Fig. 2a and b). A certain degree of diffusion driven surface accommodation was possible at longer microwave-assisted hydrothermal treatment times, ensuring the rod-like aspect. The arrows indicate the presence of defects in the interfacial attachment region of the primary particles (Fig. 2c). They indicated that the oriented attachment process was the effective growth mechanism of the products obtained under microwave-
assisted hydrothermal conditions. The presence of nanospheres attached to nanorods in the same crystallographic plane was observed for the sample synthesized at 160 C (Fig. 2d). The nanostructures appeared to grow along the length direction of the (111) crystallographic plane and along the diameter of the (002) plane, indicating the formation of nanorods with preferential growth in the [110] direction. They indicated that the driving force for the coalescence process in the oriented attachment mechanism is related to the reduction of surface energy.
Cupric oxide (CuO) has promising applications in batteries, supercapacitors, solar cells, gas sensors, catalysis, field emissions, and waste water treatment, etc. Volanti et al. provide evidence for both heterogeneous nucleation at the mesoscopic scale and the progression of the nonclassical crystallization process during the microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of tenorite phase of CuO with a sea urchin-like morphology and a monoclinic structure [20]. CuO was composed of sea urchin-like architectures with diameters of around 2.2 mm (Fig. 3b) and the spines for the sea urchin-like CuO were composed of triangular plates at 100 C in 15 min by microwave-assisted hydrothermal method (Fig. 3c). The monoclinic structure of CuO was indexed to (110), (11-2), and (00- 2) planes (inset of Fig. 3c). The fringe spacings were measured to be 0.27 nm and 0.25 nm, assigned to the planes (110) and (002), respectively, meaning the [11-2] direction of the bisector of the triangle. Urchin-like architectured CuO nanomaterials were synthesized in Cu(CH3COO)2 (0.1 M)/urea (0.5 M) and Cu(NO3)2 (0.1 M)/urea (0.5 M) aqueous systems at 150 C for 30 min via a facile microwave-assisted hydrothermal process, and the asprepared materials displayed excellent catalytic and electrochemical performance [21]. Their electrochemical properties were compared as supercapacitor electrodes using cyclic voltammetry. It was found that the increase in specific surface area promoted the catalytic activities.
A rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was employed for the fabrication of pancake-like Cd(OH)2 superstructures by the layer-by-layer self-assembly of nanosheets, employing cadmium acetate and hydrazine hydrate as the starting materials in amixed solvents of water and glycerol at 150 C for 10min [22]. The as-obtained Cd(OH)2 superstructures exhibited an enhanced photocatalytic activity for the decomposition of rhodamine B under basic conditions.

Gd2O3 nanorods and nanotubes were also produced by the 450 C and 2 h annealing of the Gd(OH)3 nanorod and nanotube precursors and self-templates, which were obtained by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal process using Gd(NO3)3 solutions containing NaOH and NH4OH as the pH buffer, respectively [24].
Titania nanowires with the anatase phase and diameters of ca. 80e150 nm and lengths ranging from several micrometers to tens of micrometers were synthesized from commercial anatase TiO2 nanoparticles using microwave-assisted hydrothermal method at 210 C for 2 h [25]. It was reported that the titania nanowires could be obtained in a shorter reaction time for only 2 h and lower thermal energy by a microwave-assisted hydrothermal process, in comparison with the conventional hydrothermal method. Arin et al. presented an inkjet printing approach suited for the deposition of photocatalytically active transparent TiO2 films from a TiO2 nanoparticles aqueous suspension, which was obtained by microwave-assisted hydrothermal treatment of titanium propoxide aqueous solutions in the presence of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and triethanolamine at 110e140 C [26]. It was reported that the complete synthesis time was significantly reduced from over 24 h to 5 min by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method compared with the classical hydrothermal synthesis.
Mulinari et al. developed an efficient microwave-hydrothermal method for the synthesis of single-crystalline Co3O4 spinel nanocubes for improving the application performancewithout using any surfactants [27], as shown in Fig. 5. The SAED pattern showed a poorly defined hexagonal spot pattern and some particles exhibited a degree of amorphous nature at 140 C for 10 min, indicating the relatively poor single-crystallinity of these products. They observed b-Co(OH)2 phase (disk-like) and Co3O4 (nanocubes) and an increase in the crystallinity of the product and the topotactic transformation to (111) plane of Co3O4 for longer duration of the synthesis at 140 C for 60 min. They proposed a possible growth mechanism for Co3O4 nanocubes based on a mesoscale self-assembly process. The Co3O4 nanocubes have promising applications in photocatalysis, solar cells and optoelectronic devices, etc.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Electrochemical applications
sections.text:
The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was developed to synthesize 3D nanosized flower-like a-Ni(OH)2 architectures with diameters of 700 nm - 1 mm and an interlayer spacing of 7.0 Å at 90 C for 15 min, the flower-like a-Ni(OH)2 architectures were consisted of the aggregated flakes made from many nanocrystals with diameters of 2e3 nm [28]. The as-prepared a-Ni(OH)2 was reported to have the best electrochemical activity for the electrochemical reduction of O2, compared with a-Ni(OH)2 synthesized by conventional hydrothermal methods and b-Ni(OH)2. The materials synthesized by microwave-assisted hydrothermal method showed enhance electrochemical activity for O2 reduction to OHe through a four-electron pathway.
A microwave-assisted hydrothermal technique was reported to prepare cryptomelane-type octahedral molecular sieve nanomaterials [29]. They observed amorphous manganese oxide below 80 C and crystalline phase at 100 C or above. The nanowires were produced from thin nanoflakes with increasing reaction temperatures. Chen et al. reported a coupled microwave-hydrothermal process for the preparation of crystalline polymorphs of MnO2 such as a-, b-, and g-phases with plate-, rod-, and wire-like shapes,
for electrochemical energy storage by a controllable redox reaction in the MnCl2eKMnO4 aqueous solution system [30]. This work showed a series of advantages, such as shorter reaction time, wellcrystallized polymorphic MnO2, and good electrochemical performances as electrode materials for lithium ion batteries. The asprepared MnO2 supercapacitors were found to have Faradaic reactivity sequence a- > g- > b-MnO2 upon their tunnel structures, the intercalation deintercalation reactivity of these MnO2 cathodes followed the order g- > a- > b-phase, and the conversion reactivity of theMnO2 anodes followed the order g- > a- > b-phase. The first discharge capacities were found to be larger than 1000 mAh g 1 and the capacities decreased after subsequent discharge/charge cycles. The reversible capacities were 600 and 620 mAh g 1 for pure g-MnO2 and a mixture of g-MnO2 and a little amount of b-MnO2, respectively (Fig. 6a, c). The reversible capacities were 280 and 550 mAh g 1 for pure b-MnO2 and a mixture of b-MnO2 and a little amount of g-MnO2, respectively (Fig. 6b, d). They suggested that this high capacity was attributed to the effect of the mixed MnO2 phases, which could provide more grain and phase boundaries for Liþ transfer. The capacities of pure a- and bMnO2 decreased faster than that of the mixture of b- and g-type MnO2 (Fig. 6e and f). Experimental results indicated that g-MnO2 was obtained by hydrothermal method at 160 C for 1 h and by microwave method only for 10 min. However, g-MnO2 (dominant) was obtained by microwave-hydrothermal method at 160 C for 10 min and b-MnO2 (dominant) was obtained by microwavehydrothermal method at 160 C for 1 h. Obvious, the different phases were carried out using different synthetic methods, which also played an important role in the electrochemical performances. These results also clearly demonstrated the advantages of microwave-hydrothermal method, compared with the traditional hydrothermal method and microwave method.
Graphene-wrapped CuO hybrids prepared at 180 C for 10 min by the rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal method displayed enhanced electrochemical properties [31]. As anode materials for lithium ion batteries, the hybrids were reported to exhibit high reversible capacity, good rate capability and enhanced cycling stability. Similar initial chargeedischarge curves of CuOegraphene hybrids and pristine CuO were obtained (Fig. 7a). A reversible capacity of 89 mA h g 1 for the pristine CuO and 532 mA h g 1 for the CuOegraphene hybrid was observed after 120 cycles at 0.2 A g 1 (Fig. 7b).

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Solar cells applications
sections.text:
The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was used to fabricate rutile nanorods grown directly on the top of fluorinedoped tin oxide (FTO) substrate for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) [32]. The growth temperature was found to affect the morphology of the product. Both length and diameter of the nanorods increased with increasing reaction temperatures (Fig. 8). However, the growth temperature influenced the length of the nanorods more than the diameter of the nanorods under the microwave-assisted hydrothermal conditions; the aspect ratio of the nanorods increased from 12 to 20 with the increase of the reaction temperature from 155 to 195 C for 50 min. Experimental results indicated that the nanorods grown at relatively high temperature were suitable for their application in DSSCs due to their higher specific surface area. When the nanorods were treated with TiCl4, more dye was adsorbed on the TiO2 films and the energy conversion efficiency increased to 3.7% for a 2.5 mm thick TiO2 film. It was found that the role of the nanorods in DSSCs was to increase an electron diffusion coefficient in TiO2 mesoporous films. They proposed a surface diffusion model for electrons that were injected into the rutile nanorods from dyemolecules, which might originate
from the high crystallinity of nanorods and the homogeneous contact between nanorod and coated nanoparticle layer.
Mahpeykar et al. synthesized long vertically aligned ZnO nanowire arrays with an average growth rate as high as 200 nm min 1 for the maximum microwave power level using an ultra-fast microwave-assisted hydrothermal process for 4e80 min in a solution containing zinc nitrate hexahydrate, hexamethylenetetramine, polyethylenimine, and ammonium hydroxide in deionized water [33]. The increase in the growth rate and the aspect ratio enhancement of the ZnO nanowires were clearly observed by increasing the microwave power level (Fig. 9). It was found that the microwave power level was proportional to the growth rate of the nanowires. The short-circuit current density and open-circuit voltage curves of the fabricated ZnO nanowire-based mercurochrome-sensitized solar cells indicated that the short-circuit current density increased with increasing the length of the nanowire array.
A microwave-assisted synthetic method was used to synthesize micrometer size anatase mesoporous TiO2 spheres with diameters in the range from 400 to 600 nm composed of 10 nm nanocrystals as building blocks at 200 C for 80 min, the anatase mesoporous TiO2 spheres had high specific surface area (132.49 m2 g 1) and were investigated for the application as photoanodes in dyesensitized solar cells [34]. The photovoltaic performances of dyesensitized solar cells using the photoanodes derived from hydrothermal mesoporous TiO2 spheres and the microwave-synthesized mesoporous spheres yielded overall power conversion efficiencies of 5.89 and 5.43% with the less volatile 3-methoxypropionitrile solvent electrolyte. The reaction time for the crystallization process by the microwave heating was greatly shortened from 16 h to 80 min. The microwave-synthesized mesoporous spheres were found to exhibit higher short-circuit photocurrent due to its superior scattering power in the entire visible and near-infrared regions than commercial available hydrothermal nanocrystalline material. On the optimum condition with acetonitrile-based electrolyte, the microwave-synthesized mesoporous spheres electrode was reported to deliver conversion efficiency of 6.19% and higher value of 6.92% by adding extra scattering layer of commercial paste.

sections.heading: 2.1.5. Optical applications
sections.text:
The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was used to synthesize spherical-like SnO2 nanocrystals (rutile-type structure) with sizes of around 5 nm [36]. The as-prepared SnO2 nanocrystals exhibited a markedly enhanced room temperature photoluminescence emission. Two broad bands at 438 and 764 nm of room-temperature photoluminescence emission were observed, which was associated with possible confinement effects. The relative intensity of 513 nm emission increased and the 393 nm one decreased with decreasing size of the nanospheres.
An efficient microwave-assisted hydrothermal strategy was developed for the rapid synthesis at 160 C within a fewminutes of high-quality multifunctional uniform hexagonal phase bNaGdF4:Ln3þ (Ln ¼ Yb, Er/Tm/Ho) nanocrystals with multicolour upconversion luminescence and paramagnetic properties [37]. The shape of the nanocrystals could be manipulated from rod-like to spherical just by tuning the initial reactants' concentration. It was reported that the microwave synthesis achieved a burst homogeneous nucleation and higher growth rate as well as enhanced dimensional homogeneity of the b-NaGdF4:Ln3þ nanocrystals compared with conventional hydrothermal routes. Rod-like nanocrystals with 76.4 ± 1.3 nm in length and 1.

For the NaGdF4:Yb, Er nanocrystals (Fig. 10E), three emission peaks were observed at 531.9, 546.3, and 661.1 nm by the transitions between the energy levels 4H11/2e4I15/2, 4S3/2e4I15/2 and 4F9/2e4I15/2 of erbium, respectively. The blue emission bands at 455.5 and 479.2 nm corresponding to the 1D2e3F4 and 1G4e3H6 transitions of thulium, and a strong NIR emission at 804.5 nm attributed to the 3H4e3H6 transition were observed for the NaGdF4:Yb, Tm nanocrystals (Fig. 10F). The intensity of the infrared emission at 804.5 nm was about ten times stronger than that of the visible emission. Authors suggested that the high-quality nanocrystals with multicolour upconversion luminescence and paramagnetic properties showed great potential for color displays, multiplexed labels, biosensors, magnetic resonance imagingeoptical dual-modal imaging and other applications.

sections.heading: 2.2. Metal composite oxides
sections.text: In addition to metal oxides and hydroxides functional nanomaterials discussed above, many other metal composite oxides functional nanomaterials have also been prepared by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. Table 3 provided the representative summary of the metal composite oxides via microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Photocatalytic applications
sections.text:
The microwave-hydrothermal method was used for the production of antiferroelectric sodium niobate (NaNbO3) in a cubiclike form and its intermediary phase, disodium diniobate hydrate (Na2Nb2O6$H2O), with a fiber morphology using niobic acid as the Nb raw material with NaOH [38]. The products with different structures and different morphologies could be adjusted by changing the reaction time and the concentration of the reactants. Shi et al. reported a fast process for the preparation of perovskite NaTaO3 nanocrystals using Ta2O5 and NaOH as starting materials by a microwave-assisted hydrothermal technique at 100e220 C for 5 min to 6 h [39]. NaTaO3 nanocrystals loading with NiO co-catalyst showed quite a high photocatalytic activity for overall water splitting more than two times greater than those prepared under conventional hydrothermal conditions, due to the good crystallinity and large specific surface area.
The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was adopted to synthesize pancake-like Fe2(MoO4)3 microstructures with a relatively good dispersion and diameters of ~5 mm at 150 C for 1 min [40]. The factors including the amount of nitric acid, reaction time, temperature and iron source, were found to play crucial roles in the formation of the Fe2(MoO4)3 multilayer stacked structures. They suggested that the oriented attachment and layer-by-layer selfassembly of nanosheets were responsible for the formation of these
structures. The as-prepared pancake-like Fe2(MoO4)3 displayed ferromagnetic behavior at a lower temperature and excellent photocatalytic property for the degradation of bromo-pyrogallol red. Hou et al. developed a facile and efficient microwave-assisted interfacial hydrothermal strategy to fabricate CdWO4 microspheres with a hydrophobic surface as an advanced photocatalyst for photocatalytic degradation of the dye methyl orange under ultraviolet light irradiation [41]. The as synthesized CdWO4 microspheres exhibited excellent photocatalytic degradation efficiency of 100% under ultraviolet illumination for 80 min.
The microwave-hydrothermal ionic liquid synthesis was also developed to fabricate ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles with a good photocatalytic property over phenol using Zn(CH3COO)2$2H2O and Fe(NO3)3$9H2O as the zinc and iron sources in the presence of CO(NH2)2 and the ionic liquid 1-n-butyl-3-methyl imidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim][BF4]) at 160 C for 30 min [42]. The ionic liquid [Bmim][BF4] and microwave heating temperature had significant influences on the crystal phase of the product. The ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles exhibited a high photocatalytic activity for the degradation of phenol, which was up to 73% within 360 min.
Tan et al. prepared BiVO4 powders with hierarchical structures at 200 C for 40 min by the microwave hydrothermal method using Bi(NO3)3$5H2O and NH4VO3 as raw materials at different pH values [43]. It was found that the crystal phases and shapes of BiVO4 changed with the pH value. It was clearly observed the evolution process of the BiVO4 crystals by varying the pH values of the precursors (Scheme 1). Monoclinic BiVO4 crystals with octahedron and decahedron morphologies were obtained at a pH value of 0.59. Spherical and polyhedral BiVO4 crystals with sizes in the range of 2e4 mm and mixed tetragonal and monoclinic crystal phases were obtained under the strong acid condition (pH ¼ 0.70e1.21). Rodlike and dendritic BiVO4 with a single monoclinic phase was obtainedwithin a verywide pH range (pH¼ 4.26e9.76). Spherical and polyhedral BiVO4 crystals were found to completely degrade the Rhodamine B after 2 h of ultraviolet-light irradiation. The monoclinic scheelite BiVO4 with a specific surface area (5.16 m2 g 1) exhibited the best visible-light photocatalytic activity. The experiments indicated that visible-light photocatalytic activity of BiVO4 was related to the crystal structure, morphology and specific
surface area. In this article, the pH value had an effect on the crystal phases and shapes of BiVO4 during the microwave-assisted hydrothermal approach, which further influenced visible-light photocatalytic activity of BiVO4.
Zhang et al. successfully prepared monodisperse erythrocytelike Cd2Ge2O6 superstructures with diameters of ~8 <SUP>m</ SUP>mat 180 C for 10min via amicrowave-assisted hydrothermal approach, employing Cd(Ac)2$2H2O and GeO2 as the reactants in the presence of hydrazine monohydrate [44] (Fig. 11a). The asprepared hierarchical microstructures were constructed by many nanoneedles and that there was a concave dip in the center of each superstructure (Fig. 11b and c). The clear lattice fringes confirm its single-crystalline nature (Fig. 11d). It was reported that the distances between the neighboring planes correspond to the (1-10) and (001) plane of Cd2Ge2O6, respectively. The corresponding fast Fourier transformation image and SAED pattern of the product further support the single-crystalline nature of these building units (Fig.11e and f). The volume of hydrazinemonohydratewas found to play a crucial role in the formation of the Cd2Ge2O6 architecture due to its well-known linking and base effect.
Conrad et al. prepared nanostructured CuxZn1-xAl2O4 spinels by a microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis at 150 C for 1 or 2 h and as a precursor for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3-based catalysts [45]. The asprepared CuxZn1-xAl2O4 nanoparticles had an average size of approximately 5 nm and a high specific surface area (above 250 m2 g 1). The observed lower performance of the spinel-based samples was attributed to a lack of synergetic interaction of the Cu nanoparticles with ZnO due to the incorporation of Zn2þ in the stable spinel lattice. The spinel catalyst was stable after thermal treatment up to 500 C in contrast to other Cu-based catalysts.
A hollow-nanocuboid photocatalyst of CdSnO3$3H2O with a high photocatalytic activity and good stability for gaseous benzene degradation was synthesized via a facile template-free microwave hydrothermal method [46]. The as-prepared sample prepared at 160 C for 2 h at pH 11 was found to exhibit the best photocatalytic activity and stability for the degradation of gaseous benzene under ultraviolet irradiation (l ¼ 254 nm) as compared with the other samples. The conversion rate and mineralization rate of benzene were about 12.5% and 67%, respectively, and the mineralization rate
was twice as high as that of commercial TiO2 (Degussa Co.). They suggested that the high stability for the benzene decomposition was attributed to the positive charge on the catalyst surface.
A series of alkaline earth metal stannates, MSnO3 (M2þ ¼ Ca2þ, Sr2þ, Ba2þ), were synthesized by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method and subsequent heat treatment process [47]. It
was found that the variation of M2þ radius in MSnO3 could change in the crystal structure and the photocatalytic degradation activity for methyl orange. With the increase of M2þ radius, dipole momentswere generated in octahedral units because of the octahedral tilting distortion, which facilitated the mobility of charge carriers and improved the activities of MSnO3. The activity increased with
decreasing M2þ radius, which may be due to the octahedral tilting distortion, wider band gap, and larger specific surface area. The dipole moments caused by the octahedral tilting distortion played the most important role in determining the photocatalytic activities of MSnO3. Compared with the conventional hydrothermal method, MSnO3 prepared by means of the microwave method had a positive enhancing effect on the activity.
Micro-sized decaoctahedron BaZrO3 powders as promising candidates for future catalysis applications were synthesized by means of the hydrothermal microwavemethod at 140 C for 40min [48]. Two photoluminescence emissions at 477 and 526 nm were observed, indicating the existence of different emission mechanisms. A theoretical model derived from previous first principle calculations was used to discuss the origin of the photoluminescence emission in BaZrO3 powders, relating to the local disorder in the network of both ZrO6 octahedral and dodecahedral (BaO12) hence forming the constituent polyhedron of BaZrO3 system. Barium zirconate microcrystals with a decaoctahedron shape were prepared using themicrowave assisted hydrothermal method at 140 C for 40 min following a non-classical growth process involving mesoscale self-assemblies of nanoparticles [49]. The photoluminescence spectrum of barium zirconate microcrystals can be divided into five Gaussian sub-bands.
A detailed study on the influence of microwave-assisted hydrothermal treatment time on both long-range and short-range structures of cube-like shape SrTiO3 powders superstructures was reported [50]. They carried out on short-order structural properties as well as the relationship between the local order and the SrTiO3 photocatalytic properties. It was found that the faster crystallization of SrTiO3 powders provided by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal system resulted in large distortions of TieO bond lengths which remained unchanged even for a longer microwaveassisted hydrothermal treatment time. The increase in microwave irradiation time did not affect the local symmetry around titanium atoms. Compared with the reference bulk SrTiO3, the presence of some under-coordinated TiO5 clusters were observed. The cubelike shaped SrTiO3 powders showed enhanced photocatalytic activity over the degradation of rhodamine B under visible light, associated with the presence of these under-coordinated TiO5 clusters.
Xiang et al. prepared visible-light-driven plasmonic photocatalyst AgeTiO2 nanocomposite hollow spheres by a template-free chemically-induced self-transformation strategy under microwave-hydrothermal conditions, followed by a photochemical reduction process under xenon lamp irradiation [51]. A strong surface enhanced Raman scattering effect was observed for the AgeTiO2 nanocomposite. The AgeTiO2 nanocomposite hollow spheres exhibited a high visible-light photocatalytic activity for photocatalytic degradation of rhodamine B in water, and their photocatalytic activity was higher than that of pure TiO2 and commercial Degussa P25 powders. Wang et al. fabricated graphene based AueTiO2 photocatalysts at 180 C for 1 h by a one-step microwave-assisted hydrothermal method, using Degussa P25 TiO2 powder, graphene oxide and HAuCl4 aqueous solution as the raw materials [52]. Au nanoparticles with size of 12e15 nm were uniformly deposited on the surface of the TiO2 nanoparticles, in which the thin, two-dimensional graphene sheet served as the support (Fig. 12a). The lattice fringes of the Au nanoparticles with spacings of 0.23 nm, 0.20 nm, 0.15 nm and 0.12 nm corresponded to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) lattice planes, respectively (Fig. 12b). The AueTiO2egraphene composite had a significantly increased visible light absorption and enhanced photocatalytic H2-production activity compared to the AueTiO2 composite. They indicated that the load of the Au nanoparticles broadened the visible light response of TiO2 due to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect,
and the introduction of graphene as rapid electron transfer units facilitated the space separation of photoelectron and hole pairs.
Ma et al. reported the microwave-assisted hydrothermal crystallization method to convert the amorphous titania shell of magnetic supraparticles (MSPs)@TiO2 to uniform mesoporous anatase structure for highly selective and effective enrichment of phosphopeptides at 180 C for 10 min [53]. It was observed that about 240 nm sized magnetic supraparticles with a nearly spherical morphology were composed of many discrete small nanocrystals (Fig. 13a). The well-defined core/shell structure was obtained by encapsulation with the amorphous titania shell around 90 nm (Fig. 13b). The titania shell of MSP@TiO2 was replaced by a discrete and porous structure after 10 min of microwave-assisted hydrothermal process at 180 C (Fig. 13c and d). During the microwaveassisted hydrothermal synthetic procedure, they captured the phase evolution of the TiO2 in the shell monitored as a function of the microwave-assisted hydrothermal reaction time. It observed the just formed tiny crystals at the outermost surface of the shell when the temperature reached 180 C, the amorphous TiO2 with the reaction time less than 3 min, a preliminary polycrystalline shell structure with the reaction time of 6 min, and the crystallinity of the shell at 10 min. Obvious, it is difficult to capture the phase evolution during the hydrothermal procedure.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Electrochemical applications
sections.text:
The joint contributions of M€ossbauer spectroscopy, Rietveld refinement and PDF analysis allowed a detailed study of the local order of well-crystallized olivine-type LiFePO4 as one of the most important cathode materials for high energy lithium ion batteries prepared at low temperature in a few minutes by means of the rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis [54]. The PDF analysis revealed the presence of disorder possibly due to Li/Fe exchange or to a local symmetry lowering. A 5% of anti-site defects on the lithium site were detected both by PDF as well as by M€ossbauer spectroscopy, revealing a small percentage of Fe3þ on the regular sites.
Both a novel microwave-solvothermal process and a microwave-hydrothermal process were used to synthesize highly crystalline LiFePO4 nanorods within a short reaction time of 5e15 min at < 300 C [55]. The LiFePO4/C nanocomposite was obtained by ex situ and in situ carbon coating at 700 C. The LiFePO4/C nanocomposite obtained by the microwave-solvothermal method exhibited higher initial discharge capacity than that obtained by themicrowave-hydrothermal method due to a smaller particle size, illustrating that both lithium ion diffusion and electronic conductivity play a critical role in controlling the electrochemical properties. Ji et al. reported the effects of microwave-hydrothermal conditions on the purity and electrochemical performance of orthorhombic LiMnO2 (o-LiMnO2) at 160 C for 45 min via the effective and energy-savingmicrowave-hydrothermalmethod [56]. The single-phase o-LiMnO2 exhibited the maximum discharge capacity of 228mA h g 1 and reversible capacity of 160mA h g 1 after 50 cycles at 0.1 C rate. The maximum discharge capacities of oLiMnO2 maintained at 197 and 165 mA h g 1 with the current density of 0.2 and 0.5 C, respectively. The o-LiMnO2 has potential application in the lithium-ion battery field.
Yoon and Manthiram synthesized W0$4Mo0$6O3 and carbondecorated WOx-MoO2 (x ¼ 2 and 3) nanorods with diameters ranging from 20 to 100 nm and sub-micrometer length at 180 C for 30 min by a microwave-assisted hydrothermal process [57]. Carbon-decorated WOx-MoO2 (x ¼ 2 and 3) nanorods provided good capacity retention and high rate capability, making them an attractive high-capacity anode for lithium-ion batteries. They suggested that the pH value of the reaction mixture had an important effect on the morphology. The as-synthesized W0$4Mo0$6O3
exhibited a first discharge capacity of ~1060 mA h g 1, which is slightly higher than the capacity expected for the insertion of six lithium (898 mA h g 1) intoW0.4Mo0$6O3 to form metallic and Mo. The initial Coulombic efficiency was ~72% with an irreversible capacity loss of 296 mA h g 1 in the first cycle. The as-synthesized W0$4Mo0$6O3 nanorods exhibited gradual capacity fade during cycling, retaining 20% of the initial discharge capacity after 50 cycles. Interestingly, the carbon-decorated WOx-MoO2 nanorods showed a stable capacity retention of 670mAh g 1 during 50 cycles due to the good electronic conductivity of WOx and MoO2 and the presence of the carbon buffer layer around the WOx-MoO2 nanorods. The carbon-decoratedWOx-MoO2 nanorods also showed good rate capability of ~379 and 274 mA h g 1, respectively, at 3C and 5C rates (Fig. 14b). The carbon-decorated WOx-MoO2 nanorods were found to exhibit excellent capacity retention because the carbon provided an elastic matrix for absorbing the volume expansionecontraction smoothly and prevented aggregation of the nanorods during cycling.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Optical applications
sections.text:
Nanocrystalline tetragonal barium titanate (BaTiO3) with particle sizes ranging from 30 to 100 nm were synthesized via a microwave-hydrothermal route at various fixed microwave frequencies and also using variable frequency with 1e5 s sweep times [58]. It was found that the particle sizes, morphologies, and surface areas of the products were influenced by the microwave frequency and bandwidth sweep time. Spherical particles with narrow and more uniform particle size distributions were obtained at a high microwave frequency (5.5 GHz) and variable frequency (3e5.5 GHz to 1 s), and particles with a cubic microstructure formed at the standard 2.45 GHz. The surface areas were found to decrease with the aging time using 4.0 and 5.5 GHz, but increased gradually with extended aging time in variable frequency (3e5.5 GHz to 1 s) processing.
The hydrothermal-microwave method was also used to synthesize photoluminescent crystalline BaTiO3 nanoparticles at 140 C for 10 min using chlorides as precursor salts and KOH as a
mineralizer with stoichiometric Ba/Ti ratio [59]. An intense and broad green color photoluminescence emission was observed at room temperature. The maximum profile emission (2.2 eV) was observed by means of an excitation energy of 2.54 eV (488 nm), which was smaller than the forbidden band gap energy of BaTiO3, indicating that certain localized levels within the band gap must existed. The tetragonally indicated a non-regular octahedron formation in the structure by the presence of hydroxyl groups and Ba2þ vacancies. It was reported that this method ws undeniably a genuine technique for low temperatures and short times in
comparisonwith the above mentioned methodologies, which were suggested to be the main reason for the existence of the photoluminescence emission in the BaTiO3 nanoparticles.
Single-phase crystalline needle-like Ba(Mn1/3Nb2/3)O3 complex perovskites with high aspect ratio were synthesized by the microwave-hydrothermal process through an oriented attachment mechanism [60]. It showed that theMn ions played a particular role in the lattice dynamics in complex perovskites. The use of microwaves was reported to lead to fast nucleation and production of nanosized particles, which could undergo a multiplying growth via a “cementing mechanism”. A microwave-assisted hydrothermal process was employed for the synthesis of three dimensional (3D) flower-shaped microarchitectures of NaY(WO4)2 in the presence of trisodium citrate (Na3Cit) as the chelating agent and shapemodifier and a postcalcination process [61]. NaY(WO4)2:Eu3þ phosphors displayed the luminescent properties and the optical transition properties. Highly uniform and well-crystallized NaLa(MoO4)2 microspheres were prepared by the facile microwave-assisted hydrothermal method at a low temperature without using any surfactants or templates via an oriented attachment and Ostwald ripening process [62]. The morphology and size of the products could be modified by altering the reaction temperature and time. The as-prepared NaLa(MoO4)2:Eu3þ microspheres exhibited a strong red luminescence at 613 nm due to 5D0 / 7F2 transition of Eu3þ under ultraviolet excitation. The photoluminescence intensity of NaLa(MoO4)2:Eu3þ microspheres was higher than that of polyhedrons and dendrites particles, indicating that the NaLa(MoO4)2:Eu3þ microspheres have the potential application in solid lighting technology.

sections.heading: 2.3. Inorganic biomaterials
sections.text:
This microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was also applied to synthesize the nanostructured inorganic biomaterials [63e81]. For example, it reported the rapid and sustainable synthesis of hydroxyapatite hierarchically nanostructured porous hollow microspheres consisting of hydroxyapatite nanosheets or nanorods as the building blocks by using creatine phosphate disodium salt as an organic phosphorus source in aqueous solution at 120e180 C for 10e60 min via the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method [63]. The specific surface area and average pore size of the hydroxyapatite porous hollow microspheres were 87.3 m2 g 1 and 20.6 nm, respectively. Creatine phosphate was found to play an important role in the formation of hydroxyapatite hierarchically nanostructured porous hollow microspheres. The control sample using a microwave-assisted hydrothermal method consisted of a mixture of hydroxyapatite nanorods and nanosheets and no porous hollow microspheres were observed (Fig. 15a and b). In contrast, the sample prepared by using creatine phosphate as the organic phosphorus source consisted of hydroxyapatite nanosheets/nanorods that were hierarchically assembled into nanostructured porous hollow microspheres with a relatively uniform size and the diameters of hydroxyapatite porous hollow microspheres was about 1 mm (Fig. 15cef). The as-prepared hydroxyapatite porous hollow microspheres were found to show a relatively high drug-loading capacity and protein-adsorption ability, as well as sustained drug and protein release, by using ibuprofen as a model drug and hemoglobin (Hb) as a model protein, respectively. The experiments indicated that the as-prepared hydroxyapatite porous hollow microspheres were promising for applications in biomedical fields, such as drug delivery and protein adsorption.
A surfactant-free rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was used to synthesize hydroxyapatite nanosheetassembled flower-like hierarchical nanostructures [64]. The
morphology of the product was observed to vary from flower-like to polyhedra by simple adjusting the microwave hydrothermal temperature. Fig. 16 shows that the hydroxyapatite sample prepared using Ca(CH3COO)2$H2O and NaH2PO4$2H2O by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method at 100 C for 5 min was composed of nanosheet-assembled flower-like hierarchical nanostructures. The sizes of hydroxyapatite nanosheet-assembled flower-like hierarchical nanostructures ranged from 1 to 3 mm, and the thicknesses of the nanosheets as the building blocks were less than 50 nm. These hydroxyapatite nanosheets self-assembled to form three-dimensional flower-like hierarchical nanostructures under microwave hydrothermal conditions. Hydroxyapatite nanosheet-assembled flower-like hierarchical nanostructures could be obtained at a lower temperature (100 C), and polyhedra formed at a higher temperature (200 C). The loading capacities of the as-prepared hydroxyapatite nanosheet-assembled flower-like hierarchical nanostructures for bovine serum albumin (BSA), hemoglobin (Hb) and fish sperm DNAwere determined to be 165, 164 and 112 mg g 1, respectively. The protein release process was conducted at different pH values (pH 7.2, 5.5 and 4.8) in phosphate buffer saline (PBS), and the pH-controlled protein release behavior
was found, which are promising for protein drug delivery applications.
Amorphous calcium carbonate (ACC) was also synthesized in vitro using adenosine 5’-triphosphate disodium salt (ATP) as the stabilizer and investigated the transformation of the ACC under microwave hydrothermal conditions, and ACC/ACP composite nanospheres and carbonated hydroxyapatite (CHA) nanospheres were successfully prepared at 110 and 180 C for 10 min, respectively [65]. In this strategy, ATP had twomain functions: it served as the stabilizer for ACC and the phosphorus source for ACP and CHA. The morphology and the size of the ACC precursor could be wellpreserved after microwave heating, so it provides a new method for the preparation of calcium phosphate nanostructured materials using phosphorus-containing biomolecule-stabilized ACC as the precursor. The transformation process of ATP-stabilized ACC precursor was displayed in Scheme 2 under microwave hydrothermal treatment. In addition, the as-prepared ACC/ACP composite nanospheres were found to have excellent biocompatibility and high protein adsorption capacity. We suggested that these materials have promising applications in biomedical fields such as drug delivery and protein adsorption.
2.4. Metal sulfides
A rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal method was used to prepare biocompatible silver sulfide nanoworms with sizes of about 50 nm in diameter and hundreds of nanometers in length
assembled by the misoriented attachment of multiple adjacent Ag2S nanoparticles by reacting silver nitrate and thioacetamide in the aqueous solution of the Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA) protein [82]. The as-prepared silver sulfide nanoworms were formed by self-assembly with the misoriented attachment of multiple
adjacent Ag2S nanoparticles. In vitro assays on the human cervical cancer cell line HeLa showed that the nanoworms exhibited good biocompatibility due to the presence of BSA coating.
Gu and Wang reported microwave-assisted hydrothermal fast synthesis of In2S3 interconnected nanoflowers and nanoparticles on graphene for high-performance Li-ion batteries at 140 C for 20 min using InCl3$4H2O, thioacetamide, and hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide in distilled water [83]. These as-obtained In2S3 nanoparticles and nanoflowers were found to be uniformly dispersed on graphene nanosheets, forming sandwiched particleon-sheet and flower-on-sheet nanostructures. In2S3-graphene composites as anode materials showed large reversible capacities and good cycling performances and high rate capabilities. A reversible initial lithium-extraction capacity of 1249 mA h g 1 was observed for the novel In2S3-graphene flower-on-sheet nanostructures at 70 mA g 1, which could be retained at 913, 782, 690 mA h g 1 at large currents of 700, 1400, 3500 mA g 1, respectively.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion and perspective
sections.text:
As described above, there have been many reports on the synthesis of functional nanomaterials via the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. Undoubtedly, in comparison with the conventional hydrothermal method, the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method is able to greatly reduce the reaction time, thus significantly enhance the efficiency of materials synthesis and save energy. In many cases, the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method exhibits order-of-magnitude enhancements in materials synthesis (minutes) as compared to the conventional hydrothermal method (tens of hours). The above cited papers indicate that functional nanomaterials with special structure, shape, and property can be rapidly prepared by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. The different structures, shapes, and improved properties demonstrate that the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method is not just a combination of methods.
Nevertheless, there are still some issues which need further investigation. Although a large volume of results on microwaveassisted hydrothermal method have been documented in the literature, more research should be paid on the precise control synthesis of functional nanomaterials with the chemical composition, structure, morphology, size, size distribution, and surface properties using these methods. Yes, the microwave-assisted hydrothermal methods combines the merits of microwave and hydrothermal methods, which can achieve the high temperature and high pressure for a short time from several minutes to several hours in a closed reaction system. That is not enough. During the microwave-assisted hydrothermal procedure, what are the changes on the heating temperature, pressure, vapor pressure, and other physical/chemical properties of solvents in this closed reaction system? How the reaction process from reactant to product? What are the disadvantages of microwave-assisted hydrothermal methods? Can this method produce large-scale production of functional nanomaterials? Can this method continuous synthesize functional nanomaterials? All these issues should be investigated in the near future.
The nonthermal effects of microwaves are still not fully understood in depth and are controversial. The microwave-assisted hydrothermal method can complete the synthesis at a high temperature and high pressure for a short time (serveral minutes to tens of minutes) in a closed reaction system. It is not easy to explore the detailed mechanisms of nucleation and growth of functional nanomaterials in the closed reaction system. Some papers report the coupling effect of the microwaves and hydrothermal treatment. Unfortunately, the theoretical basis and experimental evidences are
still missing. Therefore, development and application of on-line monitoring technology of microwaves is of great importance for understanding the nonthermal effects. On the other hand, it is necessary to carefully design comparative studies between the microwave heating and conventional heating to clarify some important issues such as the nonthermal effects or specific microwave effects under microwave hydrothermal conditions.
The mechanisms for the microwave-assisted hydrothermal treatment, nucleation, crystal growth, and structure-propertyapplications of functional nanomaterials at the molecular level need to be further studied in detail, which is important for us to understand the unique effects of the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. In the previous literature, it reported some examples with the excellent performance. However, what factors determined this excellent performance？ In particular, what is the relationship between this excellent performance and microwaveassisted hydrothermal methods? What are the advantages of microwave-assisted hydrothermal methods, compared with other methods? What is the intrinsic mechanism? The early works were mainly focused on the difference between microwave-assisted hydrothermal method and other methods. There are many reports on the synthesis of functional nanomaterials with different structure and different properties via the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. However, the relationship of methodstructure-property is still far away from a full understanding. More attention should be paid on the mechanisms for methodstructure-property of functional nanomaterials using microwaveassisted hydrothermal methods.
The rapid microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of nanostructured materials is currently a fast-growing area of research, and we expect that the research activities will continue to rapidly expand in the coming years.

metadata.abstractText: Developing simple, rapid, and environmentally friendly synthetic methodologies for the preparation of functional nanomaterials is of great importance for broadening and improving their potential applications. In comparison with other methods, the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method possesses and combines the merits of microwave and hydrothermal methods, which can achieve the high temperature and high pressure for a short time from several minutes to several hours in a closed reaction system. In this review, the synthesis of various types of functional nanomaterials such as metals oxides, metal composite oxides, inorganic biomaterials (hydroxyapatite and calcium carbonate), and metal sulfides via the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method is summarized. The special properties and applications of functional nanomaterials by the microwave-assisted hydrothermal method are compared with others methods. The future developments of this promising method are put forward. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
